reasoning:
Well, I’ve been asked to look under the hood at Tesla, and the first thing I’ve got to say is that it sits far outside my Circle of Competence. I’m a simple man who likes to invest in businesses I thoroughly understand—Coca-Cola, See’s Candies, insurance float—and I confess I don’t grasp the long-term economics of batteries, autonomous software or EV charging networks well enough to feel comfortable. 

As for moats, Tesla’s brand certainly has sizzle, but the auto industry is a tough, capital-hungry business, and competitors from traditional automakers to up-and-coming startups are all circling like sharks. Durable pricing power? I’m not convinced. Today’s edge often turns tomorrow’s commodity. 

Elon Musk is undeniably a visionary, but I’ve learned that my ideal manager acts like an owner, is candid with shareholders, and avoids unnecessary complexity. I admire his passion, yet his style and constant tinkering create more volatility than the kind of steady stewardship I favor. 

Tesla’s profits are real—but inconsistent—and the balance sheet masks massive ongoing capital needs. I’ve never met a business that can sustain sky-high valuations without a very predictable, fortress-like cash flow. 

Finally, at today’s price, I see no margin of safety. I’d rather own a wonderful business at a fair price than a fair business at a wonderful price. When in doubt, I simply say “no.” For me, that means passing on Tesla today. It may thrive or it may not—but it’s not a place for my dollars.
